title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #925**

Is there δ > 0 such that non-Ramsey graphs for K₃ on n vertices have independent sets of size ≫ n^(1/3+δ)?

**Status:** DISPROVED (Alon-Rödl 2005)

The answer is NO - the n^(1/3) bound cannot be improved.
mathContext: Connects multicolor Ramsey numbers to independent set sizes in graphs.

title: Non-Ramsey for K₃
content:
**isNotRamseyForTriangle G:**

There exists a 2-coloring of edges of G with no monochromatic triangle.

Equivalently, G is NOT guaranteed to have a monochromatic K₃ in every 2-coloring.
mathContext: This is the negation of the Ramsey property for triangles.

title: Independent Set
content:
**hasIndependentSetOfSize G k:**

∃S ⊆ V(G): |S| ≥ k and S is independent (no edges within S).

Equivalently, G contains a clique-free set of size k.

title: Independence Number
content:
**independenceNumber G:**

α(G) = the size of the largest independent set in G.

This is a fundamental graph parameter.

title: Multicolor Ramsey R(3,3,m)
content:
**R_3_3 m:**

The minimum n such that any graph on n vertices either:
- Is Ramsey for K₃ (every 2-coloring has monochromatic triangle), OR
- Has an independent set of size m

The problem asks about the growth rate of R(3,3,m).
mathContext: This is a multicolor generalization of the classical Ramsey number.

title: Trivial Bound
content:
**trivial_independent_set_bound:**

Every non-Ramsey graph on n vertices has an independent set of size ≫ n^(1/3).

This is the "easy" result that Erdős wanted to improve.
mathContext: This follows from basic counting arguments.

title: Erdős's Conjecture
content:
**erdos_925_conjecture:**

∃δ > 0, ∃C > 0: For all large n, every non-Ramsey graph on n vertices has α(G) ≥ C·n^(1/3+δ).

This conjecture was later DISPROVED by Alon and Rödl.

title: Ramsey Formulation
content:
**erdos_925_ramsey_form:**

∃c > 0: R(3,3,m) ≪ m^(3-c).

This is equivalent to the conjecture - both are FALSE.

title: Alon-Rödl Lower Bound
content:
**alon_rodl_lower_bound:**

R(3,3,m) ≥ m³ / (log m)^(4+o(1)).

This lower bound shows R(3,3,m) grows essentially like m³/polylog(m), NOT m^(3-c).

title: Alon-Rödl Upper Bound
content:
**alon_rodl_upper_bound:**

R(3,3,m) ≤ m³ · (log log m) / (log m)².

Combined with the lower bound, this determines R(3,3,m) up to polylogarithmic factors.
mathContext: The log log factor was later removed by Sudakov.

title: Sudakov's Improvement
content:
**sudakov_improvement:**

R(3,3,m) ≤ m³ / (log m)².

Sudakov removed the log log m factor from the upper bound.

title: Conjecture Disproved
content:
**erdos_925_disproved:**

The conjecture is FALSE.

There is NO δ > 0 giving independent sets of size n^(1/3+δ).

title: n^(1/3) is Optimal
content:
**n_one_third_is_optimal:**

The trivial bound n^(1/3) is essentially tight.

For any ε > 0, there exist non-Ramsey graphs with α(G) ≤ n^(1/3+ε).
mathContext: This follows from the Alon-Rödl lower bound on R(3,3,m).

title: Connection to #553
content:
**connection_to_553:**

Erdős Problem #553 asks related questions about Ramsey numbers.

Both problems concern bounds on multicolor Ramsey configurations.

title: Correct Growth Rate
content:
**correct_growth_rate:**

R(3,3,m) ~ m³ / (log m)^Θ(1).

Between m³/(log m)^4 and m³/(log m)².

Neither m^(3-c) nor m³ is correct.
mathContext: The truth lies in the polylogarithmic regime.

title: Easy Lower Bound
content:
**easy_lower_bound:**

∃c > 0: Every non-Ramsey graph has α(G) ≥ c·n^(1/3).

This is the starting point - Erdős asked if we can do better.

title: Summary Theorem
content:
**erdos_925_summary:**

Erdős's conjecture was disproved.

The n^(1/3) bound cannot be improved to n^(1/3+δ).

title: Problem Resolved
content:
**erdos_925_resolved:**

Erdős Problem #925 was completely resolved (disproved) by Alon and Rödl in 2005.
